job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Pensacola, FL
pros: Tuition waived. The university is nice, quiet, and very pretty.
cons: Tuition waiver does not cover school fees. Supervisors will look the other way as you are made to work a lot more hours than what you are paid for. I used to work over 20 hours every week, but was only paid for 10, and was told that I was expected to complete all tasks within 10 hours, and any time after that is a shortcoming on my part that I needed to fix on my own.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Pensacola, FL
pros: When you TA for decent professors its easy.
cons: When you have non-communicative professors its an issue.

pros: - Rewarding to work with students - Great networking opportunity

pros: Ability to learn on the job
cons: This is a great place to work

pros: Fostering environment. They hired me when I was 21 and they put as much into my career development as they did their students. The leadership shared their lives with us, and that was beautiful. The university is transitioning in major ways and their possibilities are endless. I decided to go explore my possibilities too. I grew with them, and I will forever be grateful with my time with them. Thank you UWF, for caring about your community as a whole. And thank you to my bosses for seeing so much in me and pushing me.
cons: Had to adapt to some uncomfortable hiring and firing situations. Co-workers become like family and it was rough. But we understand how business works.

pros: The atmosphere is welcoming and great.
cons: Pay is lower than private jobs.

pros: Some great faculty to work with.
cons: Understaffed and faculty are underpaid. Most people work 70+ hours. The forced 4 year graduation is hurting students.

pros: Great to work on campus as a grad student!

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Pensacola, FL
pros:
20 hours week maximum with only 2 or 3 classes to teach, depending on semester and availability 
Looks decent on a resume
cons:
Can't receive more than 20 hours per week
Low pay
Similar amount of work as professors, after 18 credit hours in a graduate degree you can be promoted to course instructor, but the workload increases and the pay stays the same. It only halves your tuition as well.
If you are considering this university for a teaching assistantship, please look for other universities first and see what they offer. They may all be like this, but it might be worth working more hours if you need to make rent.

pros: Good benefits and leave. Relaxed work environment
cons:
Few opportunities for career advancement.

Awful pay.

pros: Hours aligned with school operation.
cons: Not flexible with time off due to school demands and lacked clear communication and healthy leadership.

cons: People in administrative roles appear to be overworked in some departments. Your workload will depend on your job title.

pros: Located in Pensacola, FL, the University of West Florida is a fantastic university for employment. Great culture, coworkers and benefits as well as participation in fun events throughout the year. UWF is the place for you if higher education is a passion for you.

cons: Can be very busy during peak enrollment times of year. Sometimes not enough hours in the day to get everything done.

pros: The people and staff are wonderful to work with.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Pensacola, FL
pros:
Tuition Waiver and scholarships/grants, for sure.

This was in the mathematics department, and the work is pretty much what you'd expect: grading and running labs/workshops for the lower level math classes. The faculty I've worked with have all been very supportive and grateful for my help. If there were a complaint from the students, the faculty are quick to support the graduate assistants.  The only reason it doesn't get five stars is that I can't imagine someone truly enjoying grading. Also, if you are interested, you can even request to teach your own class.
cons: Recently lost the GA office, so you have to find your own private space to grade, but as long as you're not pressed for time, it's a big enough campus that you can walk somewhere and find someplace away from people.

pros: The benifets are amazing. as full time you get 6 semester hours free to use towards a degree for yourself or your hild or souce. You also get paid leave and sick leave. They have onsite daycare which is affordable and wonderful. Access to the gym, pool , outdoors resourses,
cons: There is a clear gap between the "higher ups" and the "lower on the todum poll"

review_title: Working for this company was that I was not given much authority to accomplish the tasks given to me.
job_title: Student Desk Assistant in Pensacola, FL
pros: My best reasons for working here is that it's a good study job, and it's convenient because it's on campus. We do ongoing training to keep our job knowledge up to date.
cons: Some challenges working here are that on occasion the higher ups such as the HD do not put in the necessary effort. The RA's and SDA's also are not given enough authority do get the job done most of the time.

pros: Working on campus with/for young people can be fun.
cons: Toxic work environment among staff, I alone was responsible for a range of tasks performed by 7+ people at smaller state universities in Florida. I constantly worked late and through lunch and was expected to "volunteer" at on campus events after hours. My supervisors never did anything to help me succeed, just demanded faster turnarounds with no tools to help it happen. I was made empty promises of gaining help or growing a team, which never came to light.

pros:
Flexible schedule - you can tailor it to your class schedule.
Excellent experience to add to your resume.
Helping people learn science is fun!
A small bio dept in a small university makes for a tight-knit learning community
cons:
Pay is minimum wage, and only up to 20 hours/wk for 3 labs (no full-time TAs)
You don't get paid for safety training (~6 hours)

pros: Lots of opportunities to interact with fellow students, be a mentor, and be in the know about what's going on in campus life. Very focused on leadership development.
cons: Since you live where you work, work-life balance is virtually non-existent. Like any job, there are a fair amount of politics at play when it comes to decision-making. It's a customer service job at it's heart, so "the resident is always right" tends to prevail in many situations.

pros: Competitive pay. Good holidays. Good atmosphere. Plenty of employee perks. Beautiful location. Always something going on at the campus. Good food options.
cons: Not a lot of room for advancement in most positions.  A lot of disgruntled employees. A lot of bad supervisors and inexperienced people with too much power and control.

pros:
+ Flexible for student jobs
+ Good learning place to get experience
+ Not very demanding
+ Good place to meet new people
cons:
- Poor salaries
- Not many chances of developing a career

pros:
Relaxed work environment.
Personal office.
Nice co-workers.
It's a student worker position and it really helped build my career. It was also extremely easy to work the hours around my school schedule while also having plenty of down time on the job that allowed me to study.
cons: After a while, the tasks become mundane and you reach a point where you aren't learning anything new on the job.

pros:
They work around your schedule
Flexible
Great atmosphere/Culture.
If shy, will get you to come out of your shell.
You work with Children

Nice sized university
Small classes

pros: As both a student and worker in the University of West Florida, it was a blast. I got to pick the times I wanted to work. I was surrounded by a nice friendly environment and I could always talk to some one about a particular issue.
cons: The only down side was the work I was doing was not a challenge, but remember I was only a student.

pros: Fantastic benefits, extremely understanding of work/life balance. The campus is beautiful, and the educational mission of the university in this community is unquestionable.
cons: There is a certain level of large company/government bureaucracy that can take place. People tend to work there so long there are few opportunities for advancement.

pros: Decent vacation and good work/life balance. Depending on what department you’re in it can be a great place to work with amazing people.
cons: Can be hard to get full time benefits (PTO and health care). Supervisors (in non-teaching roles) tend to be clueless and have no clue what they’re doing. Be careful going to HR if they don’t like you, they’ll fire you.

pros: really easy job, flexible hours, fun working with other students, great health benefits and retirement
cons: working as a student its impossible to get a raise so you will be working for minimum wage until you can't afford to pay your bills anymore and need a real job.

pros: Great Benefits including free classes.
cons: No room for growth internally, you will have to find a different position or company if you want to move up.  The faculty in certain departments looks down on everyone, even other faculty.  Leadership is unwilling to listen at times.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Pensacola, FL
pros: Flexible hours, accommodating of class schedules, apparently there are benefit options.
cons: I did not receive any formal training or HR information, so there are benefits and services I only learned about here on Glass Door or by searching through the website.

review_title: Assisting the mathematics professors was a joy.
pros: Assisting the mathematics professors was a joy.  Student really wanted your help.  Personal growth in the professional side of mathematics truly valuable.  Classes were paid for.
cons: Salary was not optimal but enough to sustain a happy lifestyle in Pensacola.

pros: Great co workers, relaxed environment. Was a great job for a grad student trying to earn some money. Matriculation helped with tuition too.
